analyzed: kāya vāc saṃvara śīlam samādadānaḥ bodhisattvaḥ śīla vipakṣam dauḥśīlyam prajahāti
translated: When the bodhisattva undertakes the morality of restraint of body and speech, he abandons immorality, which is the opposite of morality.

analyzed: bodheḥ ca saṃbhāra bhūtam bhavati tat asya śīla samādānam
translated: And that undertaking of morality becomes a provision for enlightenment.

analyzed: samāna artha tayā ca saṃgraha vastunā sattvān paripācayati
translated: And by having the same goal, he ripens beings through the means of attraction.

original: dauḥśīlyapratyayaṃ bhayamavadyaṃ vairaṃ prajahadātmānamanugṛhaṇāti sukhaṃ svapan sukhaṃ pratibudhyamānaḥ /
analyzed: dauḥśīlya pratyayam bhayam avadyam vairam prajahat ātmānam anugṛhaṇāti sukham svapan sukham pratibudhyamānaḥ
translated: By abandoning the fear, shame, enmity, and danger that result from immorality, he benefits himself, sleeping happily and waking happily.

analyzed: tathā śīlavataḥ vipratisāraḥ prāmodyam yāvat citta samādhiḥ
translated: In the same way, for one who has morality, there is no remorse, joy, up to one-pointedness of mind.

analyzed: iti evam ātmānam anugṛhṇāti
translated: Thus he benefits himself.

analyzed: sarva sattvānām ca sarva prakāraiḥ a viheṭhana tayā abhayam anuprayacchati
translated: And by not harming all beings in any way, he bestows fearlessness.

analyzed: evam param api anugṛhṇāti
translated: Thus he also benefits others.

original: Dutt tannidānañca kāyasya bhedātsugatau svargaloke deveṣūpapadyate /
analyzed: tad nidānam ca kāyasya bhedāt sugatau svarga loke deveṣu upapadyate
translated: And on account of that, after the dissolution of the body, he is reborn among the gods in a good destination, in the heavenly world.

analyzed: iti ayam catur ākāraḥ prabhāvaḥ śīlasya
translated: This is the fourfold power of morality.

analyzed: na atas uttari na atas bhūyaḥ
translated: There is no higher, no further.

analyzed: kṣamaḥ bodhisattvaḥ kṣānti vipakṣam a kṣānti prajahāti
translated: The bodhisattva who is patient abandons impatience, which is the opposite of patience.

analyzed: bodheḥ ca saṃbhāra bhūtā sā asya kṣāntiḥ rbhavati
translated: And that patience becomes a collection for enlightenment.

analyzed: samāna artha tayā eva ca sattvān paripācayati
translated: And by having the same goal, he matures beings.

original: ātmānañca parañca mahato bhayātparitrāyamāṇastayā kṣyāntyā ātmānañca paraṃścānugṛhṇāti /
analyzed: ātmānañca paran ca mahataḥ bhayāt paritrāyamāṇaḥ tayā kṣyāntyā ātmānañca paran ca anugṛhṇāti
translated: And by protecting himself and others from great fear with that patience, he benefits himself and others.

analyzed: tatas nidānam ca bodhisattvaḥ āyatyām avaira bahulaḥ bhavati abheda bahulaḥ ca aduḥkha daurmanasya bahulaḥ
translated: And on that basis, the bodhisattva in the future has little enmity and little division, and has little suffering and dejection.

analyzed: dṛṣṭe ca dharme vipratisārī kālam karoti
translated: And in this very life, he dies without regret.

analyzed: kāyasya ca bhedāt sugatau svarga loke deveṣu upapadyate
translated: And at the breaking up of the body, he is reborn among the gods in a good destination, in a heavenly world.

original: ityayañcaturākāraḥ kṣānteḥ prabhāvo nāta uttari nāto bhūyaḥ /
analyzed: iti ayam catur ākāraḥ kṣānteḥ prabhāvaḥ na atas uttari na atas bhūyaḥ
translated: This is the fourfold power of patience. There is no higher, no further.

original: ārabdhavīryo bodhisattvo viharan vīryavipakṣaṃ kausīdyaṃ prajahāti /
analyzed: ārabdhavīryaḥ bodhisattvaḥ viharan vīrya vipakṣam kausīdyam prajahāti
translated: The bodhisattva who abides with vigor abandoned laziness, which is the opposite of vigor.

analyzed: bodheḥ ca saṃbhāra bhūtam bhavati sat niśrayaḥ ca tat vīryam
translated: And that vigor becomes a collection for enlightenment and a basis.

analyzed: samāna artha tayā eva ca sattvān paripācayati
translated: And by having the same goal, he ripens beings.

original: ārabdhavīryaśca sukhaṃ sparśaṃ viharannavyavakīrṇaḥ pāpakairakuśalairdharmaḥ pūrveṇāparaṃ viśeṣādhigamaṃ paśyan prītiprāmodyenātmānamanugṛhṇāti
analyzed: ārabdha vīryaḥ ca sukham sparśam viharan avyavakīrṇaḥ pāpakaiḥ akuśalaiḥ dharmaḥ pūrveṇa aparam viśeṣa adhigamam paśyan prīti prāmodyena ātmānam anugṛhṇāti
translated: And having begun effort, he lives happily, untroubled by evil unwholesome dharmas, seeing progress from before to after, he benefits himself with joy and delight.

original: kuśalapakṣābhiyuktaśca paraṃ na kāyena vācā vā viheṭhayati /
analyzed: kuśala pakṣa abhiyuktaḥ ca param na kāyena vācā vā viheṭhayati
translated: And being devoted to the side of virtue, he does not harm others by body or speech.

analyzed: pareṣām ca ārabdha vīrya tāyām chandam janayati
translated: And he generates enthusiasm in others for beginning effort.

analyzed: evam param api anugṛhṇāti
translated: Thus he also benefits others.

analyzed: hetu balikaḥ ca bhavati āyatyām puruṣakāra abhirataḥ ca
translated: And he has the power of cause, and is devoted to manly effort in the future.

analyzed: iti ayam catur ākāraḥ vīrya prabhāvaḥ
translated: This is the fourfold power of effort.

analyzed: na atas uttari na atas bhūyaḥ
translated: There is no more, no different.

original: dhyānaṃ samāpadyamāno bodhisattvo dhyānavipakṣaṃ kleśaṃ kāma vitarkaprītisukharūpasaṃjñādīṃścopakleśān prajahāti /
analyzed: dhyānam samāpadyamānaḥ bodhisattvaḥ dhyāna vipakṣam kleśam kāma vitarka prīti sukha rūpa saṃjñā ādīn ca upakleśān prajahāti
translated: The bodhisattva who has attained concentration abandons the afflictions that are the opposites of concentration, such as desire, discursive thought, joy, pleasure, and the notion of form, etc.

original: bodheśca saṃbhārabhūtaṃ sanniśrayabhūtaṃ bhavati tadasya dhyānam /
analyzed: bodheḥ ca saṃbhāra bhūtam sat niśraya bhūtam bhavati tat asya dhyānam
translated: And that concentration of his becomes a collection for enlightenment and a basis.

analyzed: samāna artha tayā eva ca sattvān paripācayati
translated: And by having the same goal, he ripens beings.

analyzed: dṛṣṭadharma sukha vihāra tayā ātmānam anugṛhṇāti
translated: By dwelling happily in this very life, he benefits himself.

analyzed: śānta praśānta vīta rāga citta tayā sattveṣu avyābādhyaḥ bhavan a vikopyaḥ param api anugṛhṇāti
translated: By means of a mind that is tranquil, very tranquil, and free from passion, he is not harmed by beings and does not become angry. He also benefits others.

analyzed: jñāna viśuddhiḥ abhijñā nirhāra viśuddhiḥ deva upapattiḥ ca āyatyām dhyāna phalam
translated: The result of meditation in the future is the purification of knowledge, the attainment of the superknowledges, and rebirth as a god.

original: ityeṣa caturākāro dhyānaprabhāvo nāta uttari nāto bhūyaḥ /
analyzed: iti eṣa catur ākāraḥ dhyāna prabhāvaḥ na atas uttari na atas bhūyaḥ
translated: This is the fourfold power of meditation, neither more nor less.

analyzed: prajñāvān bodhisattvaḥ prajñā vipakṣam avidyām prajahāti
translated: The wise bodhisattva abandons ignorance, which is the opposite of wisdom.

original: bodheśca saṃbhārabhūtā bhavatyasya sā prajñā /🔽dānenāpi priyavāditayāpyarthacaryayāpi samānārthatayāpi Dutt
analyzed: bodheḥ ca saṃbhāra bhūtā bhavati asya sā prajñā  dānena api priya vādi tayā api artha caryayā api samāna artha tayā api
translated: That wisdom becomes a collection for enlightenment.

analyzed: ca sattvān paripācayati
translated: By means of generosity, kind speech, beneficial actions, and consistency between words and deeds, he ripens beings.

analyzed: jñeya vastu yathārtha pratyavagama upasaṃhitena udāreṇa prīti prāmodyena ātmānam anugṛhṇāti
translated: He benefits himself with vast joy and delight, which is connected with the correct understanding of knowable things as they are.

original: sarvatra nyāyopadeśena dṛṣṭe dharme saṃparāye ca hitasukhābhyāṃ sattvānapyanugṛhṇāti /
analyzed: sarvatra nyāya upadeśena dṛṣṭe dharme saṃparāye ca hita sukhābhyām sattvān api anugṛhṇāti
translated: He benefits beings in every way with benefit and happiness in this life and the next, by teaching the Dharma correctly.

analyzed: sarva kuśala mūla parigraham ca tayā samyak karoti
translated: He also correctly accomplishes the acceptance of all wholesome roots through that wisdom.

analyzed: āyatyām ca dvividham api āvaraṇa visaṃyogam sākṣātkaroti kleśa āvaraṇa visaṃyogam jñeya āvaraṇa visaṃyogam ca
translated: And in the future, he directly realizes the separation from both kinds of obscurations, the separation from afflictive obscurations and the separation from the obscurations to omniscience.

analyzed: iti ayam catur ākāraḥ prajñāyāḥ prabhāvaḥ
translated: Thus, this is the fourfold power of wisdom.

analyzed: na atas uttari na atas bhūyaḥ
translated: There is nothing higher than this, nothing greater than this.

analyzed: ayam ucyate dharma prabhāvaḥ
translated: This is called the power of the Dharma.

analyzed: sahajaḥ prabhāvaḥ buddha bodhisattvānām katamaḥ
translated: What is the innate power of the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas?

analyzed: prakṛti jāti smaratā
translated: It is the natural recollection of past lives.

analyzed: sattvānām arthe a pratisaṃkhyāya dīrgha kālika vicitra tīvra nirantara duḥkha sahiṣṇu tā
translated: It is the ability to endure for a long time the various intense and continuous sufferings of beings without discrimination.

analyzed: sattvānām eva arthe sattva artha saṃpādakena duḥkhena modanā
translated: It is the joy in the suffering that accomplishes the aims of beings, for the sake of beings alone.

analyzed: tuṣiteṣu ca upapannasya yāvadāyus tuṣiteṣu avasthānam
translated: And it is the ability to remain in the Tusita heaven for as long as one wishes, after being reborn there.

original: tribhiśca sthānaistuṣitopapannānāṃ tadanyeṣāṃ deva putrāṇāmabhibhavaḥ divyenāyuṣā divyena varṇena divyena yaśasā /
analyzed: tribhiḥ ca sthānaiḥ tuṣita upapannānām tad anyeṣām deva putrāṇām abhibhavaḥ divyena āyuṣā divyena varṇena divyena yaśasā
translated: And it is the superiority over other celestial beings reborn in the Tusita heaven in three ways: by divine lifespan, by divine complexion, and by divine glory.

original: upapadyamānasya ca mātuḥ kukṣāvudāreṇāvabhāsena lokadhātuspharaṇaṃ saṃprajānataśca mātuḥ kukṣipraveśaḥ sthānaṃ nirgamo janma ca /
analyzed: upapadyamānasya ca mātuḥ kukṣau udāreṇa avabhāsena lokadhātu spharaṇam saṃprajānataḥ ca mātuḥ kukṣi praveśaḥ sthānam nirgamaḥ janma ca
translated: And it is the ability to illuminate the world with vast light upon being conceived in the mother's womb, to enter the mother's womb with full awareness, to remain there, to leave it, and to be born.

analyzed: jāta mātrasya ca pṛthivyām sapta pada gamanam a parigṛhītasya a kenacid
translated: And immediately after birth, taking seven steps on the earth, without being held by anyone,

analyzed: vācaḥ ca bhāṣaṇāḥ jātasya ca udāra deva nāga yakṣa asura garuḍa kinnara mahoragaiḥ divyaiḥ mālyaiḥ vādyaiḥ dhūpaiḥ cela vikṣepaiḥ chatra dhvaja patākā ādibhiḥ vara pravarābhiḥ  pūjā karma
translated: and speaking with a voice, and being worshipped by the great gods, nāgas, yakṣas, asuras, garuḍas, kinnaras, and mahoragas with divine garlands, music, incense, scattering of cloth, parasols, banners, flags, and so forth, with the most excellent offerings,

analyzed: niruttaraiḥ ca dvātriṃśatā mahāpuruṣa lakṣaṇaiḥ su lakṣita gātra tā
translated: and having a body well-marked with the unsurpassed thirty-two marks of a great man,

original: carame ca bhave paścime janmani sarvapratyarthikairmārānīkairapi sarvopakramaiścābādhyatā /
analyzed: carame ca bhave paścime janmani sarva pratyarthikaiḥ māra anīkaiḥ api sarva upakramaiḥ ca abādhya tā
translated: and in the last existence, in the final birth, being unassailable by all adversaries, Māra's armies, and all kinds of harm,

analyzed: bodhimaṇḍe ca niṣaṇṇasya maitryā sarva māra bala parājayaḥ
translated: and after sitting at the seat of enlightenment, conquering all of Māra's power with loving-kindness,

analyzed: sarva parvasu ca ekaikasmin nārāyaṇa bala sanniviṣṭa tā
translated: and having the strength of Nārāyaṇa in each of the joints,

analyzed: dahrasya eva kumārakasya svayam eva kauśala kṛtāvinaḥ
translated: and as a young boy, being skilled in the arts by oneself,

analyzed: sarva laukika śilpasthānānām tvarita tvaritam anupraveśaḥ
translated: and quickly and swiftly entering into all worldly crafts and arts,

original: svayañcānācārya kamekākina eva ca trisāhasramahāsāhasre mahābodherabhisaṃbodhaḥ /
analyzed: svayam ca an ācārya kam ekākinaḥ eva ca tri sāhasra mahā sāhasre mahā bodheḥ abhisaṃbodhaḥ
translated: and by oneself, without a teacher, and alone, attaining great enlightenment in the great trichiliocosm,

original: brahmaṇā ca sahāṃpatinā svayamupasaṃkramya loke saddharmadeśanāyai adhyeṣaṇā /
analyzed: brahmaṇā ca sahāṃpatinā svayam upasaṃkramya loke saddharma deśanāyai adhyeṣaṇā
translated: And Brahmā, lord of the Sahā world, himself approached and requested the Bodhisattva to teach the true Dharma in the world.

analyzed: mahā megha rava a pratisaṃvedanā
translated: Not being aware of the sound of a great rain cloud.

analyzed: a vyutthāna tayā ca samāpatteḥ śānta tā
translated: And the peacefulness of the meditative absorption due to not rising from it.

original: bodhisattve ca mṛgapakṣiṇāmapyantataḥ kṣudramṛgāṇāmapi paramā viśvāsyatā /
analyzed: bodhisattve ca mṛga pakṣiṇām api antatas kṣudra mṛgāṇām api paramā viśvāsya tā
translated: And the highest confidence in the Bodhisattva even of animals, birds, and even small animals.

analyzed: sarvakālam upasaṃkramaṇam tasya ca antike yathākāma vihāri tā
translated: Always approaching him and staying near him as they wish.

original: Dutt tiraścāmantikāttathāgatasya pūjā tadyathā markaṭo madhvaneḍakaṃ tathāgatāyānupradattavān /
analyzed: tiraścām antikāt tathāgatasya pūjā tat yathā markaṭaḥ madhvaneḍakam tathāgatāya anupradattavān
translated: Worship of the Tathāgata by animals, such as when a monkey offered honey to the Tathāgata.

original: pratigṛhīte ca tasmin bhagavatā sa markaṭo hṛṣṭamānasaḥ pratyavasṛṣṭaḥ sa nṛtyamānaḥ /
analyzed: pratigṛhīte ca tasmin bhagavatā sa markaṭaḥ hṛṣṭa mānasaḥ pratyavasṛṣṭaḥ sa nṛtyamānaḥ
translated: And when the Blessed One accepted it, the monkey, with a joyful mind, departed, dancing.

original: bhagavantamevoddiśya tathāgataḥ snāsyati taṃ snāpayiṣyāmīti meghapratīkṣaṇā /
analyzed: bhagavantam eva uddiśya tathāgataḥ snāsyati tam snāpayiṣyāmi iti megha pratīkṣaṇā
translated: Waiting for clouds, thinking The Tathāgata will bathe, I will bathe him.

original: vṛkṣamūle ca bodhisattvasya tathāgatasya vā santiṣṭhatastasya sarvavṛkṣāṇāṃ prācīnanimnāsu chāyāsu tasya vṛkṣasya chāyayā kāyāvijahanatā /
analyzed: vṛkṣa mūle ca bodhisattvasya tathāgatasya vā santiṣṭhataḥ tasya sarva vṛkṣāṇām prācīna nimnāsu chāyāsu tasya vṛkṣasya chāyayā
translated: And when the Bodhisattva or the Tathāgata is standing at the foot of a tree, the shadow of all the other trees slopes towards that tree, but the shadow of that tree does not leave his body.

analyzed: ṣaḍbhiḥ varṣaiḥ abhisaṃbuddha bodheḥ tathāgatasya avatāra gaveṣiṇaḥ pi mārasya a labdha avatāra tā
translated: For six years after attaining enlightenment, the Tathāgata, even when sought to be found fault with by Māra, was not found fault with.

analyzed: sārūpya sahagatāyāḥ ca smṛteḥ satata samitam pratyupasthāna tā
translated: And he was always and constantly attended by mindfulness accompanied by equanimity.

original: smṛtasya ca pratisaṃviditānāṃ vedanānāṃ saṃjñānāṃ vitarkāṇāmutpādaḥ sthānaṃ nirodhaśca /
analyzed: smṛtasya ca pratisaṃviditānām vedanānām saṃjñānām vitarkāṇām utpādaḥ sthānam nirodhaḥ ca
translated: And for the one who is mindful, the arising, duration, and cessation of feelings, perceptions, and thoughts are fully known.

analyzed: tathā darśana anugraha karaḥ sahajaḥ prabhāvaḥ buddhānām ārya cāra vihāra saṃgṛhītaḥ ca
translated: Similarly, the innate power of the Buddhas, which benefits by being seen, and which is included in the noble conduct and way of life,
Among them, the one that benefits by being seen is as follows:

original: tadyathā unmattāḥ kṣiptacittāḥ tathāgataṃ dṛṣṭvā svacittaṃ pratilabhante /
analyzed: tat yathā unmattāḥ kṣipta cittāḥ tathāgatam dṛṣṭvā sva cittam pratilabhante
translated: For example, the insane and those with disturbed minds, upon seeing the Tathāgata, regain their right mind.

analyzed: viloma garbhāḥ striyaḥ anuloma garbhāḥ bhavanti
translated: Women with breech babies have normal deliveries.

analyzed: andhāḥ cakṣūṃṣi pratilabhante badhirāḥ śrotrāṇi
translated: The blind regain their sight, the deaf their hearing.

original: raktānāṃ rāgaparyavasthānāṃ vigacchati dviṣṭānāṃ dveṣaparyavasthānaṃ mūḍhānāṃ mohaparyavasthānam /
analyzed: raktānām rāga paryavasthānām vigacchati dviṣṭānām dveṣa paryavasthānam mūḍhānām moha paryavasthānam
translated: For the passionate, the affliction of passion disappears, for the hateful the affliction of hatred, for the deluded the affliction of delusion.

analyzed: iti ayam evaṃbhāgīyaḥ darśana anugraha karaḥ sahajaḥ prabhāvaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: This kind of innate power that benefits by being seen should be understood.

analyzed: tatra ārya cāra vihāra saṃgṛhītaḥ sahajaḥ prabhāvaḥ
translated: Among them, the innate power included in the noble conduct and way of life is as follows:

analyzed: tat yathā dakṣiṇena pārśvena siṃha śayyām kalpayati
translated: For example, he arranges his bed on his right side like a lion.

analyzed: sa ca asya tṛṇa parṇa saṃstaraḥ eka pārśva adhiśayitaḥ bhavati
translated: And that bed of grass and leaves is lain on by him on one side.

analyzed: a vikopitaḥ tathāgata arhat samyaksaṃbuddhaḥ śayānaḥ
translated: The Tathāgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One lies down without being disturbed.

analyzed: na ca asya vāyuḥ kāyāt cīvaram apakarṣati  siṃhagatim api gacchati
translated: And the wind does not pull his robe off his body.🔽He goes with the gait of a lion.

analyzed: ṛṣabhagatim api gacchati
translated: He goes with the gait of a bull.

analyzed: dakṣiṇam pādam tad prathamatas uddharati
translated: He first raises his right foot.

original: tato vāmena pādenānugacchati /🔽gacchataścāsya uccā bhūmipradeśā nīcā bhavanti /
analyzed: tatas vāmena pādena anugacchati  gacchataḥ ca asya uccāḥ bhūmi pradeśāḥ nīcāḥ bhavanti
translated: Then he follows with his left foot.🔽And as he goes, the high places of the ground become low for him.

analyzed: nīcāḥ śca uccāḥ  samāḥ pāṇi tala jātāḥ
translated: And the low places become high.🔽They are even, like the palm of the hand.

analyzed: apagata pāṣāṇa śarkara kapālāḥ
translated: Free from stones, pebbles, and potsherds.

original: vivekanimnena ca cittena grāmaṃ praviśati /🔽praviśataścāsya nīcāni dvārāṇi uccāni bhavanti /
analyzed: viveka nimnena ca cittena grāmam praviśati  praviśataḥ ca asya nīcāni dvārāṇi uccāni bhavanti
translated: And he enters the village with a mind inclined to seclusion.🔽And as he enters, the low doors become high for him.

analyzed: āhāram āharataḥ na eka odana pulākam api ati bhinnam praviśati
translated: When he takes food, not even a single grain of rice or bean enters him excessively.

original: na cāvaśiṣṭaṃ bhavati yāvad dvitīyamālopaṃ Dutt
analyzed: na ca avaśiṣṭam bhavati yāvat dvitīya ālopam
translated: And there is nothing left over until the second lump of food.

analyzed: prakṣipati
translated: He throws it away.

analyzed: iti ayam evaṃbhāgīyaḥ ārya cāra vihāra saṃgṛhītaḥ prabhāvaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: This kind of power should be understood as included in the noble conduct and dwelling.

original: parinirvāṇasamaye ca mahāpṛthivīcāla ulkāpātā diśo dāhā antarikṣe devadundubhīnāmabhinadanam /
analyzed: parinirvāṇa samaye ca mahā pṛthivīcāle ulkā pātāḥ diśaḥ dāhāḥ antarikṣe deva dundubhīnām abhinadanam
translated: And at the time of parinirvana, there is a great earthquake, falling meteors, fires in the directions, and the beating of celestial drums in the sky.

original: so 'pi sahaja eva tathāgatānāṃ prabhāvo nābhijñāsaṃskṛtaḥ /
analyzed: saḥ pi sahajaḥ eva tathāgatānām prabhāvaḥ na abhijñā saṃskṛtaḥ
translated: That power of the Tathagatas is also innate, not produced by higher knowledge.

analyzed: ayam buddha bodhisattvānām sahajaḥ prabhāvaḥ iti ucyate
translated: This is called the innate power of the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas.

analyzed: tatra katamaḥ buddha bodhisattvānām śrāvaka pratyekabuddhaiḥ asādhāraṇaḥ prabhāvaḥ
translated: Herein, what is the power of the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas that is not shared with the Shravakas and Pratyekabuddhas?

analyzed: katamaḥ ca sādhāraṇaḥ
translated: And what is shared?

analyzed: asādhāraṇa tā samāsatas tribhiḥ ākāraiḥ veditavyā
translated: The lack of sharing should be known in brief in three ways:

analyzed: sūkṣmataḥ prakārataḥ dhātutaḥ ca
translated: By subtlety, by type, and by realm.

original: iha tathāgato bodhisattvo vā 'prameyāsaṃkhyeyānāṃ sattvānāmaprameyāsaṃkhyena prabhāvopāyena yathā 'rthakriyā bhavati tadyathābhūtaṃ prajānāti
analyzed: iha tathāgataḥ bodhisattvaḥ vā prameya asaṃkhyeyānām sattvānām aprameya asaṃkhyena prabhāva upāyena yathā rthakriyā bhavati tat yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: Here, the Tathagata or the Bodhisattva knows as it truly is, by means of immeasurable and innumerable methods of power, how to accomplish the aims of immeasurable and innumerable beings.

analyzed: evam sūkṣmatas
translated: Thus it is subtle.

original: sarvaprakāreṇa cābhijñāprabhāveṇa dharmaprabhāveṇa sahajena prabhāveṇa samanvāgato bhavati /
analyzed: sarva prakāreṇa ca abhijñā prabhāveṇa dharma prabhāveṇa sahajena prabhāveṇa samanvāgataḥ bhavati
translated: He is endowed with the power of the superknowledges, the power of the Dharma, and the innate power in all its aspects.

analyzed: evam prakārataḥ
translated: This is the kind of power.

analyzed: sarva lokadhātavaḥ sarva sattvadhātavaḥ ca asya prabhāva viṣayaḥ ca bhavati
translated: All world spheres and all realms of sentient beings are the domain of his power.

analyzed: evam dhātutaḥ
translated: This is the realm of his power.

original: śrāvakasya tu saha sattvadhātunā dvisāhasro lokadhāturabhijñāviṣayaḥ /
analyzed: śrāvakasya tu saha sattvadhātunā dvi sāhasraḥ lokadhātuḥ abhijñā viṣayaḥ
translated: But for the disciple, the domain of the superknowledges is the twofold thousand world spheres together with the realm of sentient beings.

analyzed: pratyekabuddhasya sarvaḥ eva tri sāhasraḥ bhijñā viṣayaḥ
translated: For the Solitary Buddha, the entire threefold thousand world spheres is the domain of the superknowledges.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is this?

original: tathā hi te ekasyaivātmano damāya pratipannāḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi te ekasya eva ātmanaḥ damāya pratipannāḥ
translated: Because they are intent on subduing only their own self,

analyzed: no tu sarva sattvānām
translated: but not that of all sentient beings.

analyzed: tasmāt teṣām ekaḥ eva dhātuḥ parama prabhāva viṣayaḥ bhavati
translated: Therefore, for them, only one realm is the supreme domain of their power.

original: etānākārān sthāpayitvā buddhabodhisattvānāṃ tadanyaḥ prabhāvaḥ śrāvakapratyekabuddhaiḥ sādhāraṇo veditavyaḥ /
analyzed: etān ākārān sthāpayitvā buddha bodhisattvānām tad anyaḥ prabhāvaḥ śrāvaka pratyekabuddhaiḥ sādhāraṇaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: Except for these aspects, the power of the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas should be understood as common with that of the disciples and Solitary Sages.

original: tadevaṃ sati śrāvakapratyekabuddhā eva tāvadbuddhabodhisattvaiḥ saha na tulyābhijñā bhavanti /
analyzed: tat evam sati śrāvaka pratyekabuddhāḥ eva tāvat buddha bodhisattvaiḥ saha na tulya abhijñāḥ bhavanti
translated: Thus, in this way, the disciples and Solitary Sages themselves do not have equal superknowledge with the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas.

analyzed: kutas punar sarve deva manuṣyāḥ tīrthyāḥ pṛthagjanāḥ ca
translated: Why then all gods, humans, tīrthikas, and ordinary people?

analyzed: yaḥ ca api prātihārya prabhāvaḥ buddha bodhisattvānām ṛddhi ādeśanā anuśāsti saṃgṛhītaḥ saḥ
translated: And that miraculous power of the buddhas and bodhisattvas, which is included in the miraculous power of teaching through supernatural power and instruction,

original: 'pyabhijñāprabhāva eva yathāyogaṃ praviṣṭo veditavyaḥ ṛddhiviṣayacetasaḥ paryāyāsravakṣayajñānābhijñāprabhāveṣu /
analyzed: pi abhijñā prabhāvaḥ eva yathāyogam praviṣṭaḥ veditavyaḥ ṛddhi viṣaya cetasaḥ paryāya āsrava kṣaya jñāna abhijñā prabhāveṣu
translated: should be understood as included in the miraculous power of the higher knowledges, as appropriate, among the higher knowledges of supernatural power, knowledge of others' minds, and knowledge of the destruction of defilements.

analyzed: bodhisattva bhūmau ādhāre yogasthāne pañcamam prabhāva paṭalam  dutt  paripākapaṭalam chapter
translated: In the stage of practice in the foundation of the bodhisattva stage, the fifth chapter on miraculous power.🔽The Chapter on Maturation

analyzed: tatra paripākaḥ katamaḥ
translated: What is maturation?

original: paripākaḥ samāsataḥ ṣaḍbhirākārairveditavyaḥ /🔽svabhāvato 'pi paripācya pudgalato 'pi paripākaprakārabhedato 'pi paripākopāyato 'pi paripācakapudgalato 'pi paripakvapudgalalakṣaṇato 'pi
analyzed: paripākaḥ samāsatas ṣaḍbhiḥ ākāraiḥ veditavyaḥ  svabhāvataḥ pi paripācya pudgalataḥ pi paripāka prakāra bhedataḥ pi paripāka upāyataḥ pi paripācaka pudgalataḥ pi paripakva pudgala lakṣaṇataḥ pi
translated: In brief, maturation should be understood through six aspects.

analyzed: ca
translated: Through its nature, through the person to be matured, through the varieties of the process of maturation, through the means of maturation, through the person who brings about maturation, and through the characteristics of the person who is being matured.

analyzed: tatra ayam paripāka svabhāvaḥ
translated: Herein, this is the nature of maturation:

original: kuśaladharmavīje sati kuśalānāṃ dharmāṇāmāsevanānvayād yā kleśajñeyāvaraṇaprahāṇaviśuddhyanukūlā
analyzed: kuśala dharma vīje sati kuśalānām dharmāṇām āsevana anvayāt yā kleśa jñeya āvaraṇa prahāṇa viśuddhi anukūlā
translated: When there is a seed of wholesome dharmas, due to the practice of cultivating wholesome dharmas, there is a tendency towards the purification of the abandonment of the obscurations of afflictions and the knowable,🔽which is

original: kāyacittakarmaṇyatā kalyatā samyak prayoganiṣṭhā yatra sthitāḥ śāstāraṃ vā āgamyānāgamya🔽vā śāstāraṃ bhavyo bhavati pratibalo 'nantaraṃ kleśāvaraṇaprahāṇaṃ vā sākṣātkartuṃ
analyzed: kāya citta karmaṇya tā kalya tā samyak prayoga niṣṭhāḥ yatra sthitāḥ śāstāram vā āgamya an āgamya  vā śāstāram bhavyaḥ bhavati pratibalaḥ nantaram kleśa āvaraṇa prahāṇam vā sākṣātkartum
translated: The pliability of body and mind is the state of being ready, the culmination of right practice, in which one, whether relying on a teacher or not,

analyzed: jñeya āvaraṇa prahāṇam vā
translated: is fit and able to directly realize the abandonment of either the afflictive obstructions or the obstructions to omniscience immediately after.

original: tadyathā vraṇo yadā paripāṭanāya niṣṭhāgato bhavatyanantaraṃ pāṭanārhaḥ /
analyzed: tat yathā vraṇaḥ yadā paripāṭanāya niṣṭhā gataḥ bhavati anantaram pāṭana arhaḥ
translated: For example, a wound is said to be ripe when it has reached the point of being ready to be drained, and is fit to be drained immediately after.

original: saḥ paripakva ityucyate /🔽ghaṭaghaṭīśarāvādi ca mṛnmayaṃ bhāṇḍaṃ yadā paribhogāya niṣṭhāgataṃ bhavati anantaraṃ paribhogārha tadā parikvamityucyate /

analyzed: iti evaṃbhāgīyāḥ pṛthagvidhā paricaryām veditavyāḥ

analyzed: nigrahaḥ katamaḥ
translated: What is restraint?

original: ātmagatāṃ saṃkleśārakṣāṃ saṃvidhāya skhalitacodanā mṛdau vyatikrame /
analyzed: ātma gatām saṃkleśa ārakṣām saṃvidhāya skhalita codanāḥ mṛdau vyatikrame
translated: It is the admonition of one who has erred, with mild punishment, after arranging one's own protection against the afflictions.

analyzed: madhye vyatikrame vasā adanā
translated: In the middle, punishment.

analyzed: adhimātre vyatikrame pravāsanā
translated: In the case of a serious transgression, banishment.

original: tatra yā ca codanā yā cāvasādanā sā teṣāmeva hitasukhārthaṃ tadanyeṣāñca /🔽yā punaḥ pravāsanā punaḥ pratisaṃharaṇāya sāpi teṣāṃ cānyeṣāṃ ca hitasukhāya /
analyzed: tatra yā ca codanā yā ca avasādanā sā teṣām eva hita sukha artham tad anyeṣām ca  yā punar pravāsanā punar pratisaṃharaṇāya sā api teṣām ca anyeṣām ca hita sukhāya
translated: There, both accusation and punishment are for the benefit and well-being of those very [monks] and others.🔽But that banishment which is for the purpose of reconciliation is also for the benefit and well-being of those [monks] and others.

original: yā punarapratisaṃhāryā pravāsanā sā pareṣāmeva hitasukhāya /🔽tathāhi pareṣāṃ pravāsanāṃ vyatikramanidānam /
analyzed: yā punar apratisaṃhāryā pravāsanā sā pareṣām eva hita sukhāya  tathā hi pareṣām pravāsanām vyatikrama nidānam
translated: But that banishment which is not to be reconciled is only for the benefit and well-being of others.🔽For thus, banishment of others is the cause of transgression.

analyzed: pareṣu upalabhya a vyatikramāya cetayate
translated: Having observed in others [the cause of transgression], one reflects for the purpose of non-transgression.

analyzed: katham svayam paripācayati
translated: How does one ripen oneself?

original: ānulomikañca dharmaṃ deśayati akuśalāt sthānādyutthāpya kuśale sthāne pratiṣṭhāpanāya /
analyzed: ānulomikaḥ ca dharmam deśayati akuśalāt sthānāt ādi utthāpya kuśale sthāne pratiṣṭhāpanāya
translated: One teaches the Dharma that is in accordance with [the Dharma], in order to lift [beings] from unwholesome states and establish them in wholesome states.

analyzed: yathāvādī ca bhavati tathākārī
translated: And one acts as one speaks.

analyzed: dharma anudharma pratipannaḥ tad svabhāva anuvartī
translated: One practices in accordance with the Dharma, following its nature.

analyzed: yena enam pare na evam āha
translated: By which others do not say of one:

original: tvameva tāvat svayaṃ nākuśalātsthānādyutthitaḥ kuśale ca sthāne pratiṣṭhitaḥ kasmāttvaṃ tatra paraṃ samādāpayitavyaṃ codayitavyaṃ smārayitavyaṃ 🔽manyase /
analyzed: tvam eva tāvat svayam na akuśalāt sthāna ādi utthitaḥ kuśale ca sthāne pratiṣṭhitaḥ kasmāt tvam tatra param samādāpayitavyam codayitavyam smārayitavyam  manyase
translated: You yourself have not yet risen from the unwholesome and are not established in the wholesome. Why do you think you should exhort, encourage, and remind others there?

analyzed: tvam eva tāvat paraiḥ codayitavyaḥ smārayitavyaḥ samādāpayitavyaḥ
translated: You yourself should be exhorted, reminded, and encouraged by others.

analyzed: katham param adhyeṣate
translated: How does one request others?

analyzed: yasya antike sattvānām adhimātraḥ ca prema gauravam niviṣṭam bhavati
translated: One requests one in whose presence beings have planted great love and respect,

analyzed: yaḥ ca upāya jñaḥ bhavati dharma deśanāyām su śikṣitaḥ
translated: and who is skilled in means, well-trained in teaching the Dharma.

original: stamadhyeṣate vyāpārayati paripākāya /🔽ubhābhyāmābhyāṃ samastābhyāṃ svaparādhyeṣaṇākṛtaḥ paripāko veditavyaḥ /
analyzed: stam adhyeṣate vyāpārayati paripākāya  ubhābhyām ābhyām samastābhyām su apara adhyeṣaṇā kṛtaḥ paripākaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: One requests them to bring about maturation.🔽Maturation should be known as being done by both oneself and others through these twenty-seven kinds of means of maturation.

original: ityanena saptaviṃśatividhena paripākopāyena sā ṣaḍvidhā paripākaprabheda saṃpadveditavyā /
analyzed: iti anena saptaviṃśatividhena paripāka upāyena sā ṣaḍvidhā paripāka prabheda saṃpad veditavyā
translated: The six kinds of maturation should be known as being accomplished by these.

original: indriyaparipākasya kuśalamūlaparipākasya jñānaparipākasya mṛdumadhyādhimātrasya ca paripākasya /
analyzed: indriya paripākasya kuśala mūla paripākasya jñāna paripākasya mṛdu madhya adhimātrasya ca paripākasya
translated: The maturation of faculties, the maturation of roots of good, the maturation of knowledge, and the maturation of the small, middling, and great.

analyzed: tatra paripācakāḥ pudgalāḥ katame
translated: What are the individuals who bring about maturation?

original: samāsataḥ ṣaṭ bodhisattvāḥ ṣaṭasu bodhisattvabhūmiṣu vyavasthitāḥ sattvān paripācayanti /🔽adhimukticaryābhūmisthito Dutt
analyzed: samāsatas ṣaṭ bodhisattvāḥ ṣaṭasu bodhisattva bhūmiṣu vyavasthitāḥ sattvān paripācayanti  adhimukti caryā bhūmi sthitaḥ
translated: In brief, six bodhisattvas, established in the six bodhisattva stages, mature beings.

analyzed: bodhisattvaḥ dhimukti cārī
translated: The bodhisattva abiding in the stage of faithful practice is a faithful practitioner.

analyzed: śuddha adhyāśaya bhūmi sthitaḥ bodhisattvaḥ śuddha adhyāśayaḥ
translated: The bodhisattva abiding in the stage of pure superior intention has pure superior intention.

analyzed: caryā pratipatti bhūmi sthitaḥ bodhisattvaḥ caryā pratipannaḥ  niyata bhūmi sthitaḥ bodhisattvaḥ niyata patitaḥ
translated: The bodhisattva abiding in the stage of practice of conduct is engaged in the practice of conduct.🔽The bodhisattva abiding in the stage of certainty is one who has attained certainty.

analyzed: niyata caryā pratipatti bhūmi sthitaḥ bodhisattvaḥ niyata caryā pratipannaḥ
translated: The bodhisattva abiding in the stage of practice of certain conduct is engaged in the practice of certain conduct.

analyzed: niṣṭhā gamana bhūmi sthitaḥ bodhisattvaḥ niṣṭhāgataḥ
translated: The bodhisattva abiding in the stage of arrival at the culmination is one who has arrived at the culmination.

original: tatrāgotrasthānāṃ pudgalānāṃ sugatigamanāya paripākaḥ punaḥ punaḥ pratyāvartyo bhavati punaḥ punaḥ karaṇīyaḥ /
analyzed: tatra a gotra sthānām pudgalānām sugati gamanāya paripākaḥ punar punar pratyāvartyaḥ bhavati punar punar karaṇīyaḥ
translated: There, the maturation of persons who are not of the lineage is for the sake of going to good destinies. It is to be repeated again and again, to be done again and again.

original: gotrasthānāṃ punaḥ paripāko na pratyāvartyo bhavati na punaḥ punaḥ karaṇīyaḥ /
analyzed: gotrasthānām punar paripākaḥ na pratyāvartyaḥ bhavati na punar punar karaṇīyaḥ
translated: But the maturation of those who are of the lineage is not to be repeated. It is not to be done again and again.

analyzed: tatra paripakva pudgala lakṣaṇam katamat
translated: What are the characteristics of a person who is fully matured?

original: śrāvakaḥ pūrvakuśalābhyāsād yadāmṛdupākavyavasthito bhavati sa mṛducchando bhavati
analyzed: śrāvakaḥ pūrva kuśala abhyāsāt yadā a mṛdu pāka vyavasthitaḥ bhavati sa mṛducchandaḥ bhavati
translated: A śrāvaka, due to previous practice of virtue, when established in weak ripening, has weak aspiration

original: mṛduprayogaścāpāyānapi gacchati na ca dṛṣṭe dharme śrāmaṇyaphalamadhigacchati na
analyzed: mṛdu prayogaḥ ca apāyān api gacchati na ca dṛṣṭe dharme śrāmaṇya phalam adhigacchati na
translated: and weak practice, goes to the lower realms, and does not attain the fruit of asceticism in this very life, and

analyzed: ca dṛṣṭe dharme parinirvāti
translated: does not attain final nirvāṇa in this very life.

original: yadā tu madhyapākavyavasthito bhavati sa madhyacchandaśca bhavati madhyaprayogo na cāpāyān gacchati /
analyzed: yadā tu madhya pāka vyavasthitaḥ bhavati sa madhya chandaḥ ca bhavati madhya prayogaḥ na ca apāyān gacchati
translated: But when established in middling ripening, he has middling aspiration and middling practice, and does not go to the lower realms.

analyzed: dṛṣṭe ca dharme śrāmaṇya phalam prāpnoti
translated: And he attains the fruit of asceticism in this very life.

analyzed: no tu dṛṣṭe dharme parinirvāti
translated: But he does not attain final nirvāṇa in this very life.

original: adhimātre paripāke sthitaḥ adhimātracchando bhavati adhimātraprayogaśca na cāpāyān gacchati /
analyzed: adhimātre paripāke sthitaḥ adhimātra chandaḥ bhavati adhimātra prayogaḥ ca na ca apāyān gacchati
translated: Established in strong ripening, he has strong aspiration and strong practice, and does not go to the lower realms.

analyzed: dṛṣṭe ca dharme śrāmaṇya phalam prāpnoti
translated: And he attains the fruit of asceticism in this very life.

analyzed: dṛṣṭe eva ca dharme parinirvāti
translated: And he attains final nirvāṇa in this very life.

analyzed: pratyekabuddhaḥ tathā eva veditavyaḥ yathā śrāvakaḥ
translated: A pratyekabuddha should be understood in the same way as a śrāvaka.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: What is the reason for that?

analyzed: tulya jātīyaḥ sya mārgaḥ śrāvakaiḥ
translated: His path is of the same kind as that of the śrāvakas.

analyzed: śrāvakebhyaḥ pratyekabuddhasya viśeṣaḥ
translated: But this is the difference between a pratyekabuddha and a śrāvaka:

original: paścime bhave paścime ātmabhāvapratilambhe 'nācāyakaṃ pūrvābhyāsavaśāt saptatriṃśadvodhipakṣyān dharmān bhāvayitvā sarvakleśaprahāṇādarhattvaṃ
analyzed: paścime bhave paścime ātma bhāva pratilambhe na ācāyakam pūrva abhyāsa vaśāt saptatriṃśat vodhi pakṣyān dharmān bhāvayitvā sarva kleśa prahāṇāt arhat tvam
translated: In his last existence, in his last body, without a teacher, through the power of former practice, having cultivated the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, he attains arhatship through the abandonment of all defilements.

analyzed: sākṣātkaroti
translated: In his last existence, in his last acquisition of a body, without a teacher, by the power of former practice, having cultivated the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, he attains arhatship through the abandonment of all defilements.

analyzed: tasmāt pratyekabuddhaḥ iti ucyate
translated: Therefore he is called a pratyekabuddha.

original: bodhisattvaḥ punaradhimukticaryābhūmisthito muduparipāko veditavyaḥ /🔽adhyāśayaśuddho caryāpratipattibhūmau ca madhyaparipākaḥ /
analyzed: bodhisattvaḥ punar adhimukti caryā bhūmi sthitaḥ mudu paripākaḥ veditavyaḥ  caryā pratipatti bhūmau ca madhya paripākaḥ
translated: A bodhisattva, on the other hand, who is established in the stage of faithful practice should be known as having weak maturity.🔽One of pure superior intention, in the stage of practice through devotion, has medium maturity.

analyzed: niyātaḥ niṣṭhitaḥ ca adhimātra paripākaḥ
translated: One who is destined and perfected has great maturity.

original: tatra mṛdupākavyavasthito bodhisattvo mṛducchando bhavati mṛduprayogaḥ apāyāṃśca gacchati /
analyzed: tatra mṛdu pāka vyavasthitaḥ bodhisattvaḥ mṛdu chandaḥ bhavati mṛdu prayogaḥ apāyān ca gacchati
translated: There, the bodhisattva who is established in weak maturity has weak aspiration and weak practice, and goes to the lower realms.

analyzed: prathama kalpa asaṃkhyeya paryantataḥ ca sa veditavyaḥ
translated: He should be known as being at the end of the first incalculable eon.

original: uttaptairacalaiḥ suviśuddhaiśca bodhipakṣyaiḥ kuśalaidharmaiḥ sarvaireva visaṃyukto bhavati /
analyzed: uttaptaiḥ acalaiḥ su viśuddhaiḥ ca bodhi pakṣyaiḥ kuśalaiḥ dharmaiḥ sarvaiḥ eva visaṃyuktaḥ bhavati
translated: He is completely devoid of all the wholesome factors of enlightenment, which are sharp, unshakable, and well-purified.

analyzed: madhya pākaḥ bodhisattvaḥ madhya chandaḥ bhavati madhya prayogaḥ
translated: The bodhisattva with medium maturity has medium aspiration and medium practice.

analyzed: na ca apāyān gacchati dvitīya kalpa asaṃkhyeya paryantataḥ ca bhavati
translated: And he does not go to the lower realms, and he becomes one who has reached the end of the second incalculable eon.

analyzed: uttaptaiḥ acalaiḥ ca bodhi pakṣyaiḥ kuśalaiḥ dharmaiḥ  saṃyuktaḥ bhavati
translated: He is endowed with the wholesome factors that are conducive to enlightenment, which are intense, unshakable, and well-ascertained.

analyzed: su viśuddhaiḥ visaṃyuktaḥ
translated: He is endowed with those that are well-purified, and he is free from those that are not well-purified.

analyzed: adhimātra pāka sthitaḥ bodhisattvaḥ adhimātra chandaḥ bhavati adhimātra prayogaḥ ca
translated: The bodhisattva who is established in the intense ripening has intense aspiration and intense application.

analyzed: na ca apāyān gacchati
translated: And he does not go to the lower realms.

analyzed: tṛtīya kalpa asaṃkhyeya paryantataḥ ca bhavati
translated: And he becomes one who has reached the end of the third incalculable eon.

analyzed: uttaptaiḥ acalaiḥ su viśuddhaiḥ bodhi pakṣyaiḥ kuśalaiḥ dharmaiḥ samanvāgataḥ bhavati
translated: He is endowed with the wholesome factors that are conducive to enlightenment, which are intense, unshakable, and well-purified.

analyzed: tatra prakṛtyāḥ ghana tvāt ujjvala tvāt adhimātra mahā phala tvāt mahā anuśaṃsa tvāt ca uttaptāḥ iti ucyante
translated: There, they are called intense because they are naturally dense, brilliant, of great fruit, and of great benefit.

analyzed: a pratyāvartya tvāt a parihāṇīya tvāt viśeṣa gāmi tvāt acalāḥ iti ucyante
translated: They are called unshakable because they are not turned back, because they are not subject to falling away, and because they go to a special place.

analyzed: bodhisattva bhūmau niruttara tvāt su viśuddhāḥ iti ucyante
translated: They are called well-purified because they are unsurpassed in the stage of the bodhisattva.

original: tatra yaścāmiṣakṛtaḥ paripāko yaśca ṛddhyāvarjanajo yaśca guhyadharmākhyānajo yaśca
analyzed: tatra yaḥ ca āmiṣa kṛtaḥ paripākaḥ yaḥ ca ṛddhi āvarjana jaḥ yaḥ ca guhya dharma ākhyāna jaḥ yaḥ ca
translated: There, the ripening that is produced by flesh, the ripening that is produced by attracting through miraculous powers, and the ripening that is produced by teaching the secret Dharma,

original: mṛduprāyogiko yaśca śrutamātrakṛtaḥ paripāka ityeṣa pañcavidhaḥ paripākaḥ dīrghakālābhyāsādapyeṣāṃ
analyzed: mṛdu prāyogikaḥ yaḥ ca śruta mātra kṛtaḥ paripākaḥ iti eṣa pañcavidhaḥ paripākaḥ dīrgha kāla abhyāsāt api eṣām
translated: And the maturation that is merely created by hearing, this fivefold maturation is due to long-term practice of these dharmas.

analyzed: dharmāṇām mṛdukaḥ eva bhavati prāk evettaka kāla abhyāsāt
translated: Even that is only slight, let alone due to such a short period of practice.

original: tadanyaistu sarvaiḥ paripākasya kāraṇaiḥ paripākasya triprakāranayo veditavyaḥ /
analyzed: tad anyaiḥ tu sarvaiḥ paripākasya kāraṇaiḥ paripākasya tri prakāra nayaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: But by all the other causes of maturation, the method of threefold maturation should be understood.

original: mṛdukenābhyāsena mṛduko madhyena madhyaḥ adhimātreṇādhimātraḥ paripāko veditavyaḥ /
analyzed: mṛdukena abhyāsena mṛdukaḥ madhyena madhyaḥ adhimātreṇa adhimātraḥ paripākaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: It should be understood that slight maturation is due to slight practice, middling due to middling, and superior due to superior.

original: tasya ca mṛdumadhyādhimātrasya paripākasyaikaikasya triprakāranayo veditavyaḥ /
analyzed: tasya ca mṛdu madhya adhimātrasya paripākasya ekaikasya tri prakāra nayaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: And for that slight, middling, and superior maturation, each should be understood to have a threefold method.

original: mṛdukasya mṛdumṛduko mṛdumadhyo mṛdvadhimātraḥ /🔽madhyasya ca madhyamṛduko madhyamadhyo madhyādhimātraḥ /
analyzed: mṛdukasya mṛdu mṛdukaḥ mṛdu madhyaḥ mṛdu adhimātraḥ  madhyasya ca madhya mṛdukaḥ madhya madhyaḥ madhya adhimātraḥ
translated: For the slight one, slight-slight, slight-middling, and slight-superior.🔽For the middling one, middling-slight, middling-middling, and middling-superior.

analyzed: adhimātrasya adhimātra mṛduḥ adhimātra madhyaḥ dhimātra adhimātraḥ
translated: For the superior one, superior-slight, superior-middling, and superior-superior.

original: ityevaṃ bhāgīyottarottaraprabhedanayenāpramāṇaḥ paripākaprabhedaḥ sattvānāṃ buddhabodhisattvakṛto veditavyaḥ /
analyzed: iti evam bhāgīya uttara uttara prabheda nayena apramāṇaḥ paripāka prabhedaḥ sattvānām buddha bodhisattva kṛtaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: Thus, this kind of immeasurable classification of maturation for beings, created by the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, should be understood through the method of progressively distinguishing higher and higher categories.

analyzed: tatra bodhisattvaḥ ebhiḥ paripāka kāraṇaiḥ yathā nirdiṣṭaiḥ ātmanaḥ ca buddha dharma paripākāya indriya paripākam
translated: There, the bodhisattva, by these causes of maturation as described, for the maturation of the Buddha qualities in himself,

analyzed: kuśala mūla paripākam jñāna paripākam ca mṛdu madhya adhimātram ca samudānayati para sattvānām ca
translated: accumulates the maturation of faculties, the maturation of roots of virtue, and the maturation of knowledge, which are weak, middling, and great, and for other beings

analyzed: para pudgalānām yāna traya niryāṇāya
translated: and other persons, for the purpose of going forth by means of the three vehicles.

analyzed: iti bodhisattva bhūmau ādhāre yogasthāne ṣaṣṭham paripāka paṭalam  dutt
translated: Thus ends the chapter on maturation, the sixth chapter in the treatise on the stages of yoga practice in the Bodhisattvabhumi.

analyzed: bodhipaṭalam chapter
translated: The Chapter on Enlightenment

analyzed: tatra bodhiḥ katamā
translated: What is enlightenment?

original: samāsato dvividhañca prahāṇaṃ dvividhañca jñānaṃ bodhirityucyate /
analyzed: samāsatas dvividham ca prahāṇam dvividham ca jñānam bodhiḥ iti ucyate
translated: In brief, it is said that enlightenment is twofold abandonment and twofold knowledge.

analyzed: tatra dvividham prahāṇam kleśa āvaraṇa prahāṇam jñeya āvaraṇa prahāṇam ca
translated: Therein, the twofold abandonment is the abandonment of the obscurations of afflictions and the abandonment of the obscurations to knowledge.

original: dvividhaṃ punarjñānaṃ yat kleśāvaraṇaprahāṇācca nirmalaṃ sarvakleśaniranubandhajñānam /
analyzed: dvividham punar jñānam yat kleśa āvaraṇa prahāṇāt ca nirmalam sarva kleśa niranubandha jñānam
translated: Moreover, the twofold knowledge is the stainless knowledge free from the bonds of all afflictions due to the abandonment of the obscurations of afflictions,

analyzed: jñeya āvaraṇa prahāṇāt ca yat sarvasmin jñeye pratihatam anāvaraṇam jñānam
translated: and the unobstructed and unobscured knowledge regarding all knowable objects due to the abandonment of the obscurations to knowledge.

analyzed: aparaḥ paryāyaḥ
translated: Another formulation is:

analyzed: śuddha jñānam sarva jñānam asaṅga jñānam ca
translated: pure knowledge, all-knowledge, and unobstructed knowledge.

original: sarvakleśavāsanāsamuddhātaścākliṣṭāyāścāvidyāyāḥ niḥśeṣaprahāṇamanuttarā samyaksaṃbodhirityucyate /🔽tatra savāsanānāṃ sarvakleśānāṃ sarvataścātyantañca prahāṇādyad jñānaṃ tacchuddhamityucyate /
analyzed: sarva kleśa vāsanā samuddhātaḥ ca akliṣṭāyāḥ ca avidyāyāḥ niḥśeṣa prahāṇam anuttarā samyaksaṃbodhiḥ iti ucyate  tatra sa vāsanānām sarva kleśānām sarvatas ca atyantam ca prahāṇāt yat jñānam tat śuddham iti ucyate
translated: And the complete abandonment of all afflictive tendencies, and the complete abandonment of undefiled nescience, is called supreme perfect enlightenment.🔽Among them, the knowledge that is the complete and total abandonment of all afflictions along with their tendencies, and the complete abandonment of undefiled nescience, is called pure.

original: sarvadhātuṣu sarvavastuṣu sarvaprakāreṣu sarvakāleṣu yadjñānamavyāhataṃ pravartate tatsarvajñānamityucyate /
analyzed: sarva dhātuṣu sarva vastuṣu sarva prakāreṣu sarva kāleṣu yat jñānam avyāhatam pravartate tat sarvajñānam iti ucyate
translated: The knowledge that operates unobstructedly in all realms, in all things, in all aspects, and at all times, is called omniscience.

analyzed: tatra dvau vā dhātū
translated: Among them, there are two kinds of realms.

analyzed: lokadhātuḥ sattvadhātuḥ ca
translated: The world realm and the realm of beings.

analyzed: tatra dvividham vastu
translated: Among them, there are two kinds of things.

analyzed: saṃskṛtam a saṃskṛtam ca
translated: The conditioned and the unconditioned.

original: tasyaiva ca saṃkṛtāsaṃskṛtasya vastuno 'pramāṇaḥ prakārabhedaḥ svalakṣaṇottarajātiprabhedena sāmānyalakṣaṇaprabhedena hetuphalaprabhedena dhātugatikuśalākuśalāvyākṛtādiprabhedena
analyzed: tasya eva ca saṃkṛta asaṃskṛtasya pramāṇaḥ prakāra bhedaḥ sva lakṣaṇa uttara jāti prabhedena sāmānya lakṣaṇa prabhedena hetu phala prabhedena dhātu gati kuśala akuśala avyākṛta ādi prabhedena
translated: And that very conditioned and unconditioned thing has immeasurable distinctions of type, by the distinction of specific characteristics and subsequent categories, by the distinction of general characteristics, by the distinction of cause and effect, by the distinction of realm, destiny, wholesome, unwholesome, indeterminate, and so on.

analyzed: tatra kālaḥ trividhaḥ
translated: Among them, time is of three kinds.

analyzed: atītaḥ na agataḥ pratyutpannaḥ ca
translated: Past, future, and present.

original: ityetatsarvadhātukaṃ sarvavastukaṃ sarvaprakāraṃ sarvakālaṃ jñānaṃ sarvajñānamityucyate /
analyzed: iti etat sarva dhātukam sarva vastukam sarva prakāram sarva kālam jñānam sarvajñānam iti ucyate
translated: This knowledge of all dharmas, all things, all aspects, and all times is called omniscience.

original: tatrāsaṅgajñānaṃ yadābhogamātrādeva sarvatrādhiṣṭhitaṃ tvaritamasaktaṃ jñānaṃ pravartate /
analyzed: tatra asaṅga jñānam yadā ābhoga mātrāt eva sarvatra adhiṣṭhitam tvaritam asaktam jñānam pravartate
translated: Among them, unobstructed knowledge is the knowledge that, by mere attention, is established everywhere, quickly and unobstructedly.

original: na punaḥ punarābhogaṃ kurvato nānyatraikābhogapratibaddhameva tajjñānaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: na punar punar ābhogam kurvataḥ na anyatra eka ābhoga pratibaddham eva tat jñānam bhavati
translated: It does not occur again and again with further attention, but rather that knowledge is bound to a single attention.

analyzed: aparaḥ paryāyaḥ
translated: Another explanation:

original: catvāriṃśaduttaramāveṇikaṃ buddhadharmaśataṃ yā ca tathāgatasyāraṇā praṇidhijñānaṃ pratisaṃvidaśca /
analyzed: catvāriṃśat uttaram āveṇikam buddha dharma śatam yā ca tathāgatasya araṇā praṇidhi jñānam pratisaṃvidaḥ ca
translated: The one hundred and forty unique qualities of a Buddha, the Tathāgata's absence of confusion, the knowledge of vows, and the analytical knowledges,

analyzed: iyam anuttarā samyaksaṃbodhiḥ ucyate
translated: are called supreme perfect enlightenment.

analyzed: tatra idam catvāriṃśat uttaram āveṇikam buddha dharma śatam
translated: Among them, these are the one hundred and forty unique qualities of a Buddha:

analyzed: dvātriṃśat mahāpuruṣa lakṣaṇāni aśīti anuvyañjanāni catasraḥ sarva ākārāḥ pariśuddhayaḥ
translated: The thirty-two marks of a great man, the eighty minor marks, the four kinds of purity,

original: daśa balāni catvāri vaiśāradyāni trīṃṇi smṛtyupasthānāni trīṇyarakṣyāṇi mahākaruṇā
analyzed: daśa balāni catvāri vaiśāradyāni trīṃṇi smṛti upasthānāni trīṇi arakṣyāṇi mahā karuṇā
translated: the ten powers, the four confidences, the three foundations of mindfulness, the three things that need not be guarded, great compassion,

analyzed: sammoṣa dharma tā
translated: the quality of being unforgetful,

analyzed: vāsanā samudghātaḥ sarva ākāra vara jñānam ca
translated: the destruction of propensities, and the knowledge of all aspects and the best of everything.

analyzed: eṣām ca buddha dharmāṇām vibhāgaḥ pratiṣṭhā paṭale bhaviṣyati
translated: And the division of these Buddha dharmas will be in the chapter on the basis.

original: tatreyaṃ paramā bodhiḥ saptabhiḥ paramatābhiryuktā yeneyaṃ sarvabodhīnāṃ parametyucyate /
analyzed: tatra iyam paramā bodhiḥ saptabhiḥ paramatābhiḥ yuktā yena iyam sarva bodhīnām paramā iti ucyate
translated: There, this supreme enlightenment is endowed with seven supremes, by which it is called supreme among all enlightenments.

original: sapta paramatāḥ katamāḥ āśrayaparamatā pratipattiparamatā sampattiparamatā jñānaparamatā prabhāvaparamatā prahāṇaparamatā vihāraparamatā ca
analyzed: sapta paramatāḥ katamāḥ āśraya paramatā pratipatti paramatā sampatti paramatā jñāna paramatā prabhāva paramatā prahāṇa paramatā vihāra paramatā ca
translated: What are the seven supremes? The supreme basis, the supreme practice, the supreme attainment, the supreme knowledge, the supreme power, the supreme abandonment, and the supreme abode.

analyzed: yat tathāgataḥ dvātriṃśatā mahāpuruṣa lakṣaṇaiḥ su lakṣita gātraḥ
translated: That the Tathāgata has a body well-marked with the thirty-two marks of a great man,

analyzed: iyam asya āśraya parama tā iti ucyate
translated: this is called his supreme basis.

original: yattathāgata ātmahitāya parahitāya bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāyai arthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanuṣyāṇāṃ pratipannaḥ /
analyzed: yat tathāgataḥ ātma hitāya para hitāya bahu jana hitāya bahu jana sukhāya loka anukampāyai arthāya hitāya sukhāya deva manuṣyāṇām pratipannaḥ
translated: That the Tathāgata is engaged for his own benefit, for the benefit of others, for the benefit of many people, for the happiness of many people, out of compassion for the world, for the welfare, benefit, and happiness of gods and humans,

analyzed: iyam asya pratipatti parama tā iti ucyate
translated: this is called his supreme practice.

original: yattathāgato niruttarābhirapratisamābhiścatasṛbhiḥ saṃpattibhiḥ samanvāgataḥ śīlasaṃpattyā dṛṣṭisaṃpattyā ācārasaṃpattyā ājīvasaṃpattyā pratipannaḥ
analyzed: yat tathāgataḥ niruttarābhiḥ apratisamābhiḥ catasṛbhiḥ saṃpattibhiḥ samanvāgataḥ śīla saṃpattyā dṛṣṭi saṃpattyā ācāra saṃpattyā ājīva saṃpattyā pratipannaḥ
translated: That the Tathāgata is endowed with four unsurpassed and unequaled attainments, with the attainment of morality, the attainment of view, the attainment of conduct, and the attainment of livelihood, and is engaged in them,

original: iayamasya sampattiparamatetyucyate /🔽yattathāgato niruttarābhirapratisamābhiścatasṛbhiḥ pratisaṃvidbhiḥ samanvāgataḥ dharmapratisaṃvidā 'rthapratisaṃvidā niruktipratisaṃvidapratibhānapratisaṃvidā
analyzed: sampatti parama tā iti ucyate  yat tathāgataḥ niruttarābhiḥ apratisamābhiḥ catasṛbhiḥ pratisaṃvidbhiḥ samanvāgataḥ dharma pratisaṃvidā rtha pratisaṃvidā nirukti pratisaṃvid apratibhāna pratisaṃvidā
translated: This is called his supremacy of attainment.

analyzed: ca
translated: That the Tathāgata is endowed with the unsurpassed, unequaled four analytical knowledges: the analytical knowledge of dharmas, the analytical knowledge of meanings, the analytical knowledge of languages, and the analytical knowledge of eloquence.

analyzed: iyam asya jñāna parama tā iti ucyate
translated: This is called his supremacy of knowledge.

original: yattathāgato niruttarābhirapratisamābhiḥ ṣaḍbhirabhijñābhiḥ samanvāgataḥ yathā pūrvanirdiṣṭābhiḥ /
analyzed: yat tathāgataḥ niruttarābhiḥ apratisamābhiḥ ṣaḍbhiḥ abhijñābhiḥ samanvāgataḥ yathā pūrva nirdiṣṭābhiḥ
translated: That the Tathāgata is endowed with the unsurpassed, unequaled six superknowledges as previously described.

analyzed: iyam tathāgatasya prabhāva parama tā iti ucyate
translated: This is called the Tathāgata's supremacy of power.

original: yattathāgataḥ savāsanasarvakleśaprahāṇena niruttareṇāpratisamena jñeyāvaraṇa prahāṇena ca samanvāgataḥ /
analyzed: yat tathāgataḥ sa vāsana sarva kleśa prahāṇena niruttareṇa apratisamena jñeya āvaraṇa prahāṇena ca samanvāgataḥ
translated: That the Tathāgata is endowed with the unsurpassed, unequaled abandonment of afflictions along with their traces, and with the abandonment of the obstructions to the knowable.

analyzed: iyam asya prahāṇa parama tā iti ucyate
translated: This is called his supremacy of abandonment.

analyzed: yat tathāgataḥ tribhiḥ niruttaraiḥ apratisamaiḥ vihāraiḥ vihārī āryeṇa vihāreṇa divyena brāhmeṇa
translated: That the Tathāgata dwells much of the time in the three unsurpassed, unequaled dwellings: the noble dwelling, the divine dwelling, and the Brahmā dwelling.

analyzed: iyam asya vihāra parama tā iti ucyate
translated: This is called his supremacy of dwelling.

analyzed: tatra śūnyatā nimitta apraṇihita vihārāḥ nirodha samāpatti vihāraḥ cāryaḥ vihāraḥ iti ucyate
translated: Among them, the abodes of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, and the abode of the attainment of cessation, are called the noble abode.

analyzed: catvāri dhyānāni ārūpya samāpattayaḥ ca divyaḥ vihāraḥ iti ucyate
translated: The four meditations and the formless attainments are called the divine abode.

analyzed: catvāri apramāṇāni brāhmaḥ vihāraḥ iti ucyate
translated: The four immeasurables are called the abode of Brahmā.

analyzed: tasmāt punar trividhāt vihārāḥ catvāraḥ parama vihārāḥ yaiḥ tathāgatāḥ tad vahula vihāriṇaḥ bhavanti
translated: Again, from these three kinds of abodes, there are four supreme abodes, by which the Tathāgatas dwell much in them.

analyzed: āryāt vihārāt śūnyatā vihāraḥ nirodha samāpatti vihāraḥ ca
translated: From the noble abodes, the abodes of emptiness and the attainment of cessation.

analyzed: divyāt vihārāt ā niṃjya caturtha dhyāna vihāraḥ
translated: From the divine abodes, the immovable fourth meditation abode.

original: brāhmādvihārātkaruṇāvihāro yena tathāgatastriskṛto rātrau triskṛtvo divase ṣaṭkṛtvo rātriṃdivena buddhacakṣaṣā lokaṃ vyavalokayati ko hīyate 🔽Dutt
analyzed: brāhmāt vihārāt karuṇā vihāraḥ yena tathāgataḥ triskṛtaḥ rātrau triskṛtvas divase ṣaṣ kṛtvas rātriṃdivena buddha cakṣaṣā lokam vyavalokayati kaḥ hīyate  / dutt
translated: From the abode of Brahmā, the abode of compassion, by which the Tathāgata looks upon the world with the eye of a Buddha three times at night and three times by day, six times in a day and night, Who is declining?

original: ko vardhate kasyānutpannāni kuśalamūlānyavaropayāmi kvaṃ yāvadvistareṇāgraphale 'rhattve pratiṣṭhāpayāmīti /
analyzed: kaḥ vardhate kasya anutpannāni kuśala mūlāni avaropayāmi kvam yāvat vistareṇa agra phale rhat tve pratiṣṭhāpayāmi iti
translated: Who is prospering? In whom shall I plant the roots of virtue that have not yet arisen? Up to in whom shall I establish in the supreme fruit of arhatship?

analyzed: tatra āśraya parama tayā tathāgatāḥ mahā puruṣāḥ iti ucyante
translated: Among them, the Tathāgatas, the great men, are called thus by the supremacy of their basis.

analyzed: pratipatti parama tayā mahā kāruṇikāḥ iti ucyante
translated: They are called greatly compassionate because of their supremacy in practice.

analyzed: saṃpatti parama tayā mahā śīla mahā dharmāṇaḥ iti ucyante  jñāna parama tayā mahā prajñāḥ iti ucyante
translated: They are called of great morality and great Dharma because of their supremacy in attainment.🔽They are called of great wisdom because of their supremacy in knowledge.

analyzed: prabhāva parama tayā mahābhijñāḥ iti ucyante
translated: They are called of great supernormal knowledge because of their supremacy in power.

analyzed: prahāṇa parama tayā mahāvimuktayaḥ iti ucyante
translated: They are called of great liberation because of their supremacy in abandonment.

analyzed: vihāra parama tayā mahā vihāra tat bahula vihāriṇaḥ iti ucyante
translated: They are called of great dwelling, frequently dwelling in that because of their supremacy in dwelling.

original: teṣāñca punastathāgatānāṃ daśabhirākārairguṇābhidhānañca bhavati guṇānusmaraṇatā ca /
analyzed: teṣām ca punar tathāgatānām daśabhiḥ ākāraiḥ guṇa abhidhānam ca bhavati guṇa anusmaraṇa tā ca
translated: And for those Tathāgatas, there are ten aspects of proclaiming their qualities and recollecting their virtues.

original: katamairdaśabhiḥ /🔽ityapi sa bhagavāṃstathāgato 'rhansamyaksaṃbuddho vidyācaraṇasaṃpannaḥ sugato lokavidanuttaraḥ puruṣadamyasārathiḥ śāstā devamanuṣyāṇāṃ buddho
analyzed: katamaiḥ daśabhiḥ  iti api sa bhagavān tathāgataḥ rhan samyaksaṃbuddhaḥ vidyā caraṇa saṃpannaḥ sugataḥ loka vid anuttaraḥ puruṣa damya sārathiḥ śāstā deva manuṣyāṇām buddhaḥ
translated: What are the ten?

analyzed: bhagavān iti
translated: That Blessed One is a Tathāgata, an Arhat, a Perfectly Enlightened One, perfect in knowledge and conduct, a Sugata, an knower of the world, an unsurpassed trainer of those who can be trained, a teacher of gods and humans, a Buddha, a Blessed One.

analyzed: tatra avitatha vacanāt tathāgataḥ
translated: Here, he is a Tathāgata because of his words that are not false.

analyzed: sarva prāptayā artha prāpta tvāt anuttara puṇya kṣetra tvāt pūjā arha tvāt ca arhan
translated: He is an Arhat because he has attained all that needs to be attained, because he is the unsurpassed field of merit, and because he is worthy of offerings.

analyzed: yathāvat parama arthena dharma anubodhāt samyaksaṃbuddhaḥ
translated: He is a Perfectly Enlightened One because he has fully awakened to the ultimate truth as it is.

analyzed: tisṛbhiḥ vidyābhiḥ yathā sūtra uktena ca caraṇena vipaśya nāśa matha pakṣa ubhaya su sampanna tvāt vidyā caraṇa sampannaḥ
translated: He is endowed with knowledge and conduct because he is well-endowed with both insight and tranquility, with the three knowledges as explained in the sutras and with the conduct.

analyzed: parama utkarṣa gamanāt apunar pratyāgamanāt ca sugataḥ
translated: He is the Sugata because he has gone to the highest excellence and does not return.

analyzed: sattvadhātu lokadhātvoḥ sarva ākāreṇa kleśa vyavadāna jñānāt loka vid
translated: He is the Knower of the World because he knows the afflictions and purification of all aspects of the realms of beings and the world.

original: paramacittadamopāyajñatayā ekasyaiva loke puruṣabhūtasya ca prādurbhāvāt anuttaraḥ puruṣadamyasārathiḥ /
analyzed: parama citta dama upāya jña tayā ekasya eva loke puruṣa bhūtasya ca prādurbhāvāt anuttaraḥ puruṣa damya sārathiḥ
translated: He is the Unsurpassed Trainer of Human Beings to be Tamed because he knows the supreme method of taming the mind, and because only one person has appeared in the world.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ bhūta tvāt jñāna artha dharma tattva bhūta tvāt vyaktasya arthasya nirṇetṛ tvāt sarva artha pratisaraṇa tvāt avyutpannasya arthasya
translated: He is the Eye because he is the truth of knowledge, meaning, and Dharma, he is the Decider because he determines the manifest meaning, he is the Refuge for all meanings because he is the unexcelled refuge for all meanings.

original: vyutpādakatvā dutpannasya saṃśayasyocchedakatvāt gambhīrāṇāṃ sthānānāṃ vivaraṇāt
analyzed: vyutpādaka tvāt utpannasya saṃśayasya ucchedaka tvāt gambhīrāṇām sthānānām vivaraṇāt
translated: He is the Expounder because he explains the unexpounded meaning, he is the Cutter-off of doubts because he cuts off the doubts of those who are confused, he is the Explicator because he explains the profound subjects.

original: paryavadāpakatvāttanmūlatvāt sarvadharmāṇāṃ tannetṛkatvāttatpratisaraṇatvāt sarvaduḥkhasya🔽niḥsaraṇaṃ śāsti vyapadiśati samyagdevamanuṣyāṇām /
analyzed: paryavadāpaka tvāt tad mūla tvāt sarva dharmāṇām tad netṛka tvāt tad pratisaraṇa tvāt sarva duḥkhasya 🔽niḥsaraṇam śāsti vyapadiśati samyak deva manuṣyāṇām
translated: He is the Teacher because he teaches the escape from all suffering, which is the root of all dharmas, and the refuge for all suffering.

original: tasmācchāstā devamanuṣyāṇāmityucyate /🔽arthopasaṃhitasya dharmarāśeranarthopasaṃhitasya dharmarāśernnaivārthopasaṃhitasya nānārthopasaṃhitasya dharmarāśeḥ sakalasarvākārābhisaṃbodhād
analyzed: tasmāt śāstā deva manuṣyāṇām iti ucyate  artha upasaṃhitasya dharma rāśeḥ anartha upasaṃhitasya dharma rāśeḥ na eva artha upasaṃhitasya na anārtha upasaṃhitasya dharma rāśeḥ sakala sarva ākāra abhisaṃbodhāt
translated: Therefore, he is called the Teacher of gods and humans.

analyzed: buddhaḥ iti ucyate  sarva māra bala mahā saṃgrāma avabhaṅgāt bhagavān
translated: He is called Buddha because he has fully awakened to all aspects of the Dharma, which is connected with meaning, which is not connected with meaning, and which is neither connected with meaning nor not connected with meaning.

analyzed: dutt
translated: He is called the Blessed One because he has completely defeated the great armies of all Maras.

original: tatra prabhūtairapi kalpairekasyāpi buddhasya prādurbhāvo na bhavati /
analyzed: tatra prabhūtaiḥ api kalpaiḥ ekasya api buddhasya prādurbhāvaḥ na bhavati
translated: Here, even with many eons, the appearance of a single Buddha does not occur.

original: ekasminneva ca kalpe prabhūtānāṃ buddhānāmutpādo bhavati /
analyzed: ekasmin eva ca kalpe prabhūtānām buddhānām utpādaḥ bhavati
translated: But in a single eon, the birth of many Buddhas does occur.

original: teṣu teṣu ca daśasu dikṣvaprameyāsaṃkhyeyeṣu lokadhātuṣvaprameyāṇāmeva buddhānāmutpādo veditavyaḥ /
analyzed: teṣu teṣu ca daśasu dikṣu aprameya asaṃkhyeyeṣu lokadhātuṣu aprameyāṇām eva buddhānām utpādaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: And in those innumerable and incalculable world systems in the ten directions, the birth of innumerable Buddhas alone should be known.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: santi daśasu dikṣu aprameya asaṃkhyeyāḥ bodhisattvāḥ ye tulya kāla kṛta praṇidhānāḥ tulya saṃbhāra samudāgatāḥ ca
translated: There are innumerable and incalculable bodhisattvas in the ten directions who have made vows at the same time and have gathered the requisites in the same way.

original: yasminneva divase pakṣe māse saṃvatsare ekena bodhisattvena bodhau cittaṃ praṇihitaṃ tasminneva divase pakṣe māse saṃvatsare sarvaiḥ /
analyzed: yasmin eva divase pakṣe māse saṃvatsare ekena bodhisattvena bodhau cittam praṇihitam tasmin eva divase pakṣe māse saṃvatsare sarvaiḥ
translated: On whatever day, fortnight, month, or year a bodhisattva first generates the mind of enlightenment, on that very day, fortnight, month, and year, all [bodhisattvas] do so.

original: yathā caika utsahito ghaṭito vyāyacchitaśca tathā sarve /
analyzed: yathā ca ekaḥ utsahitaḥ ghaṭitaḥ vyāyacchitaḥ ca tathā sarve
translated: And just as one [bodhisattva] is resolute, striving, and persevering, so are all [bodhisattvas].

original: tathāhi dṛśyante 'sminneva lokadhātāvanekāni bodhisattvaśatāni yāni tulyakālapraṇidhānāni tulyatyāgāni tulyakṣāntikāni tulyavīryāṇi tulyadhyānāni
analyzed: tathā hi dṛśyante smin eva lokadhātau anekāni bodhisattva śatāni yāni tulya kāla praṇidhānāni tulya tyāgāni tulya kṣāntikāni tulya vīryāṇi tulya dhyānāni
translated: For thus, in this very world-system, many hundreds of bodhisattvas are seen who have made vows at the same time, who have the same generosity, the same patience, the same vigor, the same meditation,

analyzed: tulya prajñānāni
translated: and the same wisdom.

analyzed: prāk eva daśasu dikṣu anantā paryanteṣu lokadhātuṣu
translated: How much more so in the endless and limitless world-systems in the ten directions.

analyzed: buddhakṣetrāṇi api tri sāhasra mahā sāhasrāṇi aprameya asaṃkhyeyāni daśasu dikṣu saṃvidyante
translated: And immeasurable and innumerable buddha-fields of three-thousand great-thousand worlds exist in the ten directions.

original: na ca tulyasaṃbhārasamudāgatayordvayostāvadbodhisattvayorekasmin lokadhātau buddhakṣetre yugapadutpattyavakāśo 'sti prāgevāprameyāsaṃkhyeyānām
analyzed: na ca tulya saṃbhāra samudāgatayoḥ dvayoḥ tāvat bodhisattvayoḥ ekasmin lokadhātau buddhakṣetre yugapad utpatti avakāśaḥ sti prāk eva aprameya asaṃkhyeyānām
translated: And there is no opportunity for two bodhisattvas who have attained the same accumulations to appear simultaneously in one world-system, one buddha-field, much less for immeasurable and innumerable [bodhisattvas].

analyzed: na ca punar tulya saṃbhārāṇām krameṇa anuparipāṭikayā utpādaḥ yujyate
translated: And it is not reasonable that those with equal accumulations would arise in sequence, one after another.

original: nāpi sarveṇa sarvamanutpāda eva yujyate /🔽tasmāddaśasu dikṣvaprameyāsaṃkhyeyeṣu lokadhātuṣu yathā pariśodhiteṣu tathāgataśūnyeṣu te tulyasaṃbhārā bodhisattvā anyonyeṣu buddhakṣetreṣūtpadyanta
analyzed: nā api sarveṇa sarvam anutpādaḥ eva yujyate  tasmāt daśasu dikṣu aprameya asaṃkhyeyeṣu lokadhātuṣu yathā pariśodhiteṣu tathāgata śūnyeṣu te tulya saṃbhārāḥ bodhisattvāḥ anyonyeṣu buddhakṣetreṣu utpadyanta  /
translated: Nor is it reasonable that they would not arise at all.

analyzed: iti veditavyam
translated: Therefore, it should be understood that in the ten directions, in immeasurable and incalculable world systems that have been purified in that way, those bodhisattvas with equal accumulations are born in other buddha-fields.

original: tadanena paryāyeṇa bahuṣu lokadhātuṣu buddhabāhulyameva yujyate /
analyzed: tat anena paryāyeṇa bahuṣu lokadhātuṣu buddha bāhulyam eva yujyate
translated: By this method, the abundance of buddhas in many world systems is reasonable.

analyzed: na ca ekasmin buddhakṣetre dvayoḥ tathāgatayoḥ yugapad utpādaḥ bhavati
translated: And the simultaneous arising of two tathāgatas in one buddha-field does not occur.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: dīrgharātram khalu bodhisattvena evam praṇidhānam anubṛṃhitam bhavati
translated: For a long time, indeed, the bodhisattva has been cultivating the vow:

original: yathāhameko 'pariṇāyake loke pariṇāyakaḥ syāṃ sattvānāṃ vinetā sarvaduḥkhebhyo vimocayitā parinirvāpayiteti /
analyzed: yathā aham ekaḥ pariṇāyake loke pariṇāyakaḥ syām sattvānām vinetā sarva duḥkhebhyaḥ vimocayitā parinirvāpayitā iti
translated: May I alone be the guide in the world, the trainer of beings, the liberator from all sufferings, the one who brings them to complete nirvāṇa, in this world without a guide.

original: yasyaivaṃ dīrgharātraṃ praṇidhānamanubṛṃhayataḥ samyak pratipattiparigṛhītamṛdhyatyeva tat /
analyzed: yasya evam dīrgharātram praṇidhānam anubṛṃhayataḥ samyak pratipatti parigṛhītam ṛdhyati eva tat
translated: For one who has been cultivating such a vow for a long time, when it is embraced by right practice, it succeeds.

original: punaśca śakta ekastathāgatastrisāhasramahāsāhasre ekasmin buddhakṣetre sarvabuddhakārya kartum /
analyzed: punar ca śaktaḥ ekaḥ tathāgataḥ tri sāhasra mahā sāhasre ekasmin buddhakṣetre sarva buddha kārya kartum
translated: Moreover, a single Tathāgata is able to perform all the Buddha's work in a single great trichiliocosm.

original: ato dvitīyasya tathāgatasya vyartha evotpādaḥ syāt /
analyzed: atas dvitīyasya tathāgatasya vyarthaḥ evā utpādaḥ syāt
translated: Therefore, the arising of a second Tathāgata would be pointless.

original: bhūyaścaikasya tathāgatasya loke utpādātsattvānām evārthakaraṇaprasiddhiḥ pracuratarā bhavati pradakṣiṇatarā /

translated: Furthermore, when a single Tathāgata appears in the world, the accomplishment and abundance of benefit for beings becomes much greater.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

original: teṣāmevaṃ bhavatyayameva kṛtsne jagatyekastathāgato na dvitīyaḥ /
analyzed: teṣām evam bhavati ayam eva kṛtsne jagati ekaḥ tathāgataḥ na dvitīyaḥ
translated: They think, This alone is the only Tathāgata in the entire world, there is no second.

original: asmiñjanapadacārikāṃ vā viprakānte parinirvṛte vā nāsti sa kaścid dvitīyaḥ /
analyzed: asmin janapada cārikām vā viprakānte parinirvṛte vā na asti sa kaścid dvitīyaḥ
translated: When he has gone on a journey to another country or has attained final nirvāṇa, there is no other second.

original: Dutt yasyāsmābhirantike brahmacaryaṃ caritavyaṃ syāt dharmo vā śrotavya iti viditvā 'titvarante ghanatareṇa chandavyāyāmena brahmacaryavāsāya
analyzed: yasya asmābhiḥ antike brahmacaryam caritavyam syāt dharmaḥ vā śrotavyaḥ iti viditvā titvarante ghanatareṇa chanda vyāyāmena brahmacarya vāsāya
translated: Knowing this, they hasten with a denser enthusiasm to live the holy life

analyzed: saddharma śravaṇāya ca
translated: and to listen to the true Dharma.

analyzed: buddha bahu tvam tu te upalabhya na atitvareran
translated: But if they perceive many Buddhas, they would not hasten so much.

original: evameṣāmekasya buddhasyotpādātsvārthe karaṇaprasiddhiḥ pracuratarā ca bhavati pradakṣiṇatarā ca /
analyzed: evam eṣām ekasya buddhasya utpādāt sva arthe karaṇa prasiddhiḥ pracuratarā ca bhavati pradakṣiṇatarā ca
translated: Thus, due to the arising of a single Buddha, the accomplishment of one's own purpose becomes more abundant and favorable.

original: tatra sarvabuddhānāṃ sarvaṃ samasamaṃ bhavati nirviśiṣṭaṃ sthāpayitvā catvāri sthānāniāyurnāma kulaṃ kāyañca /
analyzed: tatra sarva buddhānām sarvam samasamam bhavati niḥ viśiṣṭam sthāpayitvā catvāri sthānāni āyuḥ nāma kulam kāyaḥ ca
translated: Among them, all the Buddhas are exactly the same, without distinction, except for four things: lifespan, name, family, and body.

analyzed: iti eṣām caturṇām dharmāṇām hrāsa vṛddhyā vilakṣaṇa tā buddhānām
translated: The Buddhas differ in these four dharmas due to decrease and increase.

analyzed: na tu anyena kenacid
translated: But not by anything else.

analyzed: na ca strī anuttarām samyaksaṃbodhim a saṃbudhyate
translated: And a woman does not attain supreme perfect enlightenment.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: tathā hi bodhisattvaḥ prathamasya eva kalpa asaṃkhyeyasya atyayāt
translated: Because a bodhisattva, after the first incalculable eon has passed,

analyzed: strī bhāvam vijahāti
translated: abandons the female state.

original: bodhimaṇḍaniṣadanamupādāya na punarjātu strī bhavati /🔽prakṛtyā ca bahukleśo duṣprajñaśca bhavati sarvo mātṛgrāmaḥ /
analyzed: bodhimaṇḍa niṣadanam upādāya na punar jātu strī bhavati  prakṛtyā ca bahu kleśaḥ duṣprajñaḥ ca bhavati sarvaḥ mātṛgrāmaḥ
translated: From the time of sitting at the seat of enlightenment, he never again becomes a woman.

original: na ca prakṛtyā bahukleśasantānena duṣprajñasantānena ca śakyamanuttarāṃ samyaksaṃbodhimabhisaṃboddhum /
analyzed: na ca prakṛtyā bahu kleśa santānena duṣprajña santānena ca śakyam anuttarām samyaksaṃbodhim abhisaṃboddhum
translated: And a woman is by nature greatly afflicted and unwise, and it is not possible to attain supreme perfect enlightenment with a continuum greatly afflicted by nature and a continuum that is unwise.

original: evamiyamanuttarā samyaksaṃbodhiḥ svabhāvato 'pi yathānirdiṣṭā yathābhūtaṃ veditavyā /
analyzed: evam iyam anuttarā samyaksaṃbodhiḥ svabhāvataḥ yathā nirdiṣṭā yathābhūtam veditavyā
translated: Thus, this unsurpassed perfect enlightenment should be known as it truly is, according to its nature, as it has been described.

original: paramato 'pi guṇanirdeśānusmaraṇato 'pi saṃbhavato 'pi viśeṣato 'pi yathānirdiṣṭā yathābhūtaṃ veditavyā /
analyzed: paramatas pi guṇa nirdeśa anusmaraṇataḥ pi saṃbhavataḥ pi viśeṣataḥ pi yathā nirdiṣṭā yathābhūtam veditavyā
translated: It should also be known as it truly is, according to its excellence, according to the teaching of its qualities, according to its possibility, and according to its distinction, as it has been described.

analyzed: api tu acintyā eva sarva tarka mārga samatikrānta tvāt aprameya asaṃkhyeya guṇa samudita tvāt anuttarā eva ca samyaksaṃbodhiḥ sarva śrāvaka pratyekabuddha tathāgatān ābhi
translated: Moreover, this unsurpassed perfect enlightenment is inconceivable, because it transcends all paths of reasoning, and because it is endowed with immeasurable and innumerable qualities. It is the enlightenment of all śrāvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and tathāgatas.

analyzed: nirvṛttaye bhavati
translated: It is for the sake of attaining that.

analyzed: tasmāt eṣā eva bodhiḥ agryā śreṣṭhā varā praṇītā iti
translated: Therefore, this enlightenment alone is the best, the supreme, the excellent, the sublime.

analyzed: iti bodhisattva bhūmau ādhāre yogasthāne saptamam bodhi paṭalam  dutt
translated: This concludes the seventh chapter on enlightenment in the stage of yoga practice in the foundation of the bodhisattva stages.

analyzed: bala gotra paṭalam chapter

analyzed: nirdiṣṭam tāvat yatra bodhisattvena śikṣitavyam

analyzed: yathā punar śikṣitavyam tat vakṣyāmi

analyzed: uddānam  adhimukteḥ bahula tā dharma paryeṣṭi deśanā

translated: one who seeks the Dharma, one who teaches the Dharma, one who practices in accordance with the Dharma, one who gives proper instruction and admonition,

analyzed: samyak avavāda anuśāsanyāt ca sthitena upāya parigṛhīta kāya vāc manaḥ karmaṇā ca bhavitavyam
translated: and one who abides in proper instruction and admonition, with bodily, verbal, and mental action accompanied by means.

analyzed: kathañca bodhisattvaḥ dhimukti bahulaḥ bhavati
translated: And how does a bodhisattva become one who is abundant in faith?

original: iha bodhisattvo 'ṣṭavidhe 'dhimuktyadhiṣṭhāne śraddhāprasādapūrvaṃkeṇa niścayena rucyā samanvāgato bhavati /

translated: Here, a bodhisattva is endowed with faith, clear faith, conviction, and delight in the eight bases of faith.

analyzed: triṣu ratneṣu buddha dharmaṃsaṃgha guṇeṣu buddha bodhisattva prabhāve ca yathā nirdiṣṭe
translated: In the three jewels, in the qualities of the Buddha, Dharma, and Saṅgha, and in the power of the buddhas and bodhisattvas as described,

analyzed: tattva arthe ca yathā nirdiṣṭe hetau ca phale ca vicitre yathā yoga patite aviparīte prāptavye

analyzed: tatra laukikāni śilpa karma sthānāni anekavidhāni bahu nānā prakārāṇi

analyzed: tat punar kati ākāram pravartate

analyzed: buddha vacanam samāsatas dvi ākāram pravartate

translated: by illuminating the skill in curing diseases that have arisen,🔽by illuminating the skill in abandoning diseases that have arisen,

analyzed: katham ca buddha vacanam aviparītam hetu phalam paridīpayati

translated: These ten causes should be known as the unmistaken establishment of causes, which includes all causes, for the defilement or purification of mundane things, and for the occurrence of indeterminate things such as crops, etc.

analyzed: daśa hetavaḥ dutt katame
translated: The ten causes are:

analyzed: anuvyavahāra hetuḥ  apekṣā hetuḥ  ākṣepa hetuḥ
translated: The cause of conventional usage.🔽The cause of dependence.🔽The cause of projection.

analyzed: parigraha hetuḥ

analyzed: abhinirvṛtti hetuḥ  āvāhaka hetuḥ pratiniyama hetuḥ
translated: The cause of manifestation.🔽The cause of attraction. The cause of restriction.

analyzed: sahakāri hetuḥ virodha hetuḥ
translated: The cause of cooperation. The cause of opposition.

analyzed: avirodha hetuḥ ca
translated: And the cause of non-opposition.

translated: Among them, that which is dependent, that which is caused, in which there is desire and appropriation for that thing, this is called its cause of dependence.

analyzed: tat yathā hasta apekṣam hasta hetukam ādāna karma
translated: For example, the action of grasping is dependent on the hand, caused by the hand.

analyzed: pāda apekṣam pāda hetukam abhikrama pratikrama karma  parva apekṣam parva hetukam samiñjita prasārita karma
translated: Action of going forward and returning is dependent on the feet and caused by the feet.🔽Action of bending and extending is dependent on the joints and caused by the joints.

translated: Taking up food and drink and seeking them is dependent on hunger and thirst and caused by hunger and thirst.

translated: The causal relation should be understood as immeasurable in this way.

analyzed: tatra bījam āvasānikasya sva phalasya ākṣepa hetuḥ

translated: The condition other than the seed is the supporting cause.

analyzed: tat eva bījam sva phalasya nirvṛtti hetuḥ
translated: That very seed is the producing cause of its own fruit.
